page.title: 03HISTORY OF TYTHERINGTON
page.content: Tytherington is an{Anglo-Saxon}name meaning 'people of the Tytheras farm or village'. Flints suggest that people were there before Saxon times. There are also remains of an{Iron-age}fort. Some large farm-houses were built in the 16th and 17th C by wealthy farmers and cloth merchants. In the 19th C{farming}was the main occupation as shown by Kelly's Directory, 1875. In 1872{quarrying started in the area. Tytherington also had a railway station on the Thornbury branch, and a board school for 120 children. Some modern houses have been built in the 20th Century. No large scale development. Tytherington has managed to keep its village character. There is as yet no local history group.
